Denis - (10:03): réponse pour aurélie:  
Denis - (10:03): Effectivement, ce n'est pas terrible. Cependant, IE6 est sorti le 31 décembre 2001 et bien qu'il sera encore supporté par Microsoft jusqu'au 21 avril 2013 (ce qui est un record pour un tel produit), il faut remarquer que depuis ce 1/3/2010 (http://googleenterprise.blogspot.com/2010/01/modern-browsers-for-modern-applications.html), même le géant Google ne le supporte plus pour ses applications en ligne. En outre, deux nouvelles version de IE ont été publié  
Denis - (10:03): Les statistiques d'utilisation des navigateurs (cfr. http://www.w3schools.com/browsers/browsers\_stats.asp) montre aujourd'hui que l'utilisation d'IE6 représente moins de 10% du marché (13% actuellement des visites sur votre site ces 3 derniers mois), et que dans moins d'un an nous pouvons penser qu'il sera complètement disparu, par manque de support des site internet de nouvelle génération.  
Denis - (10:03): Nous portons donc tout nos efforts sur le support dIE7 et IE8, ainsi que sur les navigateurs FireFox 3.x et Safari 4.x. Il nous est dès lors aujourd'hui particulièrement difficile de justifier encore du support d'IE6. Nous vous conseillons de recommander à vos utilisateurs de réaliser la mise à jour de leur navigateur, car outre une amélioration de votre site, il profiterons également mieux de l'Internet actuel.  
Denis - (10:03): Enfin, nous sommes évidement conscient que certain d'entre eux pourrait garder un ancien navigateur pour supporté des outils d'aide aux handicapé (en particulier les mal voyant), mais il nous semble assez peu probable dans ce cas que les défauts visuels rapportés soit réellement significatif.  
Denis - (10:03): Si malgré cela, vous souhaitiez que nous portions à nouveau une attention plus poussé sur IE6, nous serions contraint de vous établir un devis pour la réalisation de cette amélioration difficilement amortissable sur d'autre clients.  
Denis - (10:03): Bien cordialement,  
Denis - (10:03): Denis  
vmassol - (10:04): interesting :)  
Denis - (10:04): oups  
Denis - (10:04): bas window  
Denis - (10:04): bad sorry  
vmassol - (10:04): we could reuse that too!  
Denis - (10:05): for sure, that is a pity to see client complaining on IE6 support  
Denis - (10:05): nearly 10 years after the release !  
Denis - (10:06): by the way, I am puzzle by an issue in XWikiDocument, could you help understand this ?  
Denis - (10:06): public String getTranslatedContent(String language, XWikiContext context) throws XWikiException  
Denis - (10:06):     {  
Denis - (10:06):         XWikiDocument tdoc = getTranslatedDocument(language, context);  
Denis - (10:06):         String rev = (String) context.get("rev");  
Denis - (10:06):         if ((rev == null) || (rev.length() == 0)) {  
Denis - (10:06):             return tdoc.getContent();  
Denis - (10:06):         }  
Denis - (10:06):         XWikiDocument cdoc = context.getWiki().getDocument(tdoc, rev, context);  
Denis - (10:06):         return cdoc.getContent();  
Denis - (10:06):     }  
Denis - (10:07): why do we get rev from context here ?  
vmassol - (10:07): right now I'm the one who needs help re relative refs…. it's hard… :)  
Denis - (10:07): :)

vmassol - (10:18): hmm actually I don't think whitespaces are stripped  
plunden - (10:18): It is part of python syntax, used to delimit blocks.  
vmassol - (10:18): (just checked the code)  
vmassol - (10:19): plunden: best is you send a mail to the list  
vmassol - (10:19): giving an example that doesn't work for you

headache - (15:35): reading from wiki Building page  
headache - (15:35): "If you download the platform and compile it then you can compile XWiki Enterprise, Maven will use your newly compiled copy of the platform rather than downloading it, Maven is smart"  
headache - (15:35): this happen when i check out XWiki enterprise in the same folder of XWiki platform?  
sdumitriu - (15:36): No, this happens from anywhere  
sdumitriu - (15:36): Maven uses a local repository where it holds packages  
sdumitriu - (15:36): When you build something, it goes in the local repo  
headache - (15:37): ~/.m2/repository  
sdumitriu - (15:37): If the local copy is more recent than the one on the remote repository, then it is used  
sdumitriu - (15:37): Otherwise the remote is downloaded  
sdumitriu - (15:37): So, if you built locally yesterday, today you'd get the official build from maven.xwiki.org  
sdumitriu - (15:38): (unless you build with -o)  
headache - (15:38): ok  
headache - (15:39): if i modify source code i will move the jar in web/tomcat/webapps/ROOT/WEB-INF ?  
headache - (15:40): there's also tomcat/webapps/ROOT/WEB-INF  
headache - (15:40): i'm referring to XWiki platform directory structure  
headache - (15:41): then start jetty or tomcat go to localhost and see results  
sdumitriu - (15:42): No, those are sources  
sdumitriu - (15:42): Wait  
sdumitriu - (15:42): What is that?  
sdumitriu - (15:42): Is that your local tomcat installation?  
headache - (15:43): no no  
headache - (15:43): are folders in repository  
headache - (15:44): from xwiki/platform/trunks  
sdumitriu - (15:45): Then those are sources, you shouldn't do anything with them  
headache - (15:45): ok  
Denis - (16:05): mflorea: hello, I would like to discuss XWIKI-5001, are you available ?  
kibahop left #xwiki at 16:11  
mflorea - (16:11): Hi Denis, sure  
florinciu joined #xwiki at 16:11  
Denis - (16:12): well, I completely understand the way it works, and why the limitation is there, and even how difficult it could be to fix i  
nickless joined #xwiki at 16:12  
Denis - (16:12): t  
Denis - (16:12): however, I do find annoying that an editor could destroy or change something when nothing has been edited  
Denis - (16:13): moreover, this depends on the browser, which is worse  
Denis - (16:13): and this could change over time depending on browser evolution  
Denis - (16:14): that is why I have reported  
Denis - (16:14): for my current situation, I had an ugly workaround:  
mflorea - (16:14): yes, I understand your point, and, as I said, it's a good think you have reported the issue. It's just that I don't see how we can fix it.  
Denis - (16:14): {{velocity}}  
Denis - (16:14): (% style='break-after: page;' %)  
Denis - (16:14): {{/velocity}}  
mflorea - (16:15): :) yes, you protected it with a macro  
mflorea - (16:15): but why not using a class?  
Denis - (16:15): just because I need to fix the pdf exporter first :à  
mflorea - (16:16): I don't see the relation  
Denis - (16:16): there were issue under 1.9 that made css not functionning, there is I think an open issue in the 2.2, so I had to check again  
sdumitriu - (16:16): Right, classnames are not kept  
sdumitriu - (16:16): I should apply that patch for 2.2.3  
mflorea - (16:17): ah, I see  
mflorea - (16:17): so currently you have to put the style inline  
Denis - (16:17): yes, it is needed  
Denis - (16:18): and we would like our user to be able to use WYSIWYG to avoid the ugliness of the source  
Denis - (16:18): they do not have to change style, but depending on their browser they loose part of it  
sdumitriu - (16:18): Denis: would upgrading to 2.2.3 be an option for you?  
mflorea - (16:19): but if using class names would work then your problem would be solved, right?  
Denis - (16:20): I had to check that, since the process of preparing PDF is really tricky and never worked the way it should  
Denis - (16:20): we will be migrating site to 2.2.x as soon as I feel it stable enough  
Denis - (16:20): and surely I will try classes for styling  
Denis - (16:22): even, if I get workaround, the way IE extends some styling will surely be annoying, maybe something coud be done their, no ?  
mflorea - (16:23): now, without using class names, I don't see how can we fix this problem. When the editor gets access to the DOM tree, the style attribute has already been changed..  
Denis - (16:23): -their+there  
mflorea - (16:23): in IE, the problem is the serialization of the DOm tree, which is also done by the browser  
Denis - (16:24): probably, but concats of similar borders is possible, no ?  
glerouge left at 16:24 (Quit: Leaving.  
sdumitriu - (16:24): Denis: IIRC, IE is actually doing you a favor, since the version of css4j that we're using doesn't support shorthand properties like border  
Denis - (16:24): not sure human agrees :)  
mflorea - (16:24): :)  
mflorea - (16:24): yes  
Denis - (16:25): I had real end user on the other side :)  
sdumitriu - (16:25): Actually I have a better solution: STOP USING IE!  
sdumitriu - (16:25): :)  
Denis - (16:25): had you missed my bad paste earlier this morning, about IE6 :)  
sdumitriu - (16:25): No, that was good  
Denis - (16:26): this is terrible how end user stay stucked on IE  
Denis - (16:27): a major reason for pushing me migrating to 2.2, is that WYSIWYG does not work on IE in 1.9 !  
mflorea - (16:27): Denis, let me locate the border problem, I want to be sure the border is "duplicated" when I get the innerHTML of the edited document and not in some other place  
mflorea - (16:28): what IE are your end users using? IE6, 7 or 8?  
Denis - (16:28): any, but I agree to leave IE6  
Denis - (16:29): I do not check it myself anymore  
Denis - (16:29): to old, and google do not supported anymore which was a great news  
mflorea - (16:34): indeed, paragraph.outerHTML "duplicates" the border stlye in IE..  
Nirmal joined #xwiki at 16:37  
Denis - (16:37): headache: When I start studying computer, Microsoft products was considered leading-edge, now I avoid them as much as I can !  
Nirmal - (16:38): headache: I need your help, regarding the installation  
headache - (16:38): Denis, my university has signed an agreement with Microsoft so students could download Microsoft development products  
headache - (16:38): a real trap  
headache - (16:38): only 4-5 professor use gnu/linux  
headache - (16:39): in my opinion is a shame...  
sdumitriu - (16:39): headache: Yes, same things in Romania  
headache - (16:40): but we're lucky C# has not entered in university courses... but it's only a question of time  
Nirmal - (16:40): headache, I've installed maven too, but what XWiki module to download is the question  
Denis - (16:40): headache: Marketing is what they do best, else the better would already happen  
headache - (16:40): Denis, no i believe that Apple is marketing Google is advertising so Microsoft and Gnu Project are software  
headache - (16:40): :D  
headache - (16:41): Nirmal, you need platform  
Nirmal - (16:41): headache, ok  
Denis - (16:41): if Apple were marketing, M$ would not have the most part of the market  
headache - (16:41): Nirmal, what you are trying to do?  
Denis - (16:42): Apple is design !  
headache - (16:42): Denis, you miss iphone & ipad products :D  
Denis - (16:42): and luxe  
Nirmal - (16:42): headache, tried to executemvn install  
Denis - (16:42): and that is why they missed the marked  
headache - (16:43): i think apple is marketing because invents new gadgets and people feel to need them  
headache - (16:43): feel...  
headache - (16:44): look at ipad spot  
headache - (16:44): it seems cool :D  
headache - (16:44): but it's a product that do nothing really well  
headache - (16:44): you cannot use it as a book reader because it uses lcd  
Denis - (16:44): this is a recent situation, it would have been better for us that it had happened earlier  
headache - (16:45): however Apple is important because when enters in a market there's a real innovation  
Denis - (16:45): developping Mac product and using them is more pleasant, more stable, better architectured, than all I have seen from M$, and the iPhone was the best of it  
headache - (16:45): i don't think so  
headache - (16:46): Apple is based on BSD  
headache - (16:46): beautiful UI
